results.title: Do you remember?
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films and Tony Thompson
results.brief_description: Day in, day out, throughout the year, the passengers on London’s buses and Underground leave behind them enough property to keep a large staff of sorters and storemen permanently busy. How the lost property is collected, sorted, ware-housed and, in most cases, restored to owners is the story of this film.

results.title: Do you mind if I smoke?
results.creator_credit: Sue Woodford and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Investigates the dangers of passive smoking, ie the smoke inhaled by a non-smoker from cigarettes left burning in an ashtray or in someone’s hand. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Do unto others
results.brief_description: Courtesy and civilised personal behaviour as the basis of road safety. How bullying, rudeness and impatience set up a series of dangerous chain reactions; various road situations showing the danger of the driver’s sense of power, and the need for courtesy as a complement to modern highway design. The risks to pedestrians, especially the old and very young. An old blind man and a schoolboy provide a story thread.

results.title: Do unto animals
results.creator_credit: United States. Dept. of Agriculture and H McClure
results.brief_description: Briefly describes the organisation and purpose of the National Livestock Loss Prevention Board. Explains how cattle, sheep and hogs may be killed or badly bruised through wrong handling on the way to slaughter-yards. Shows examples of damaged carcasses, thus resulting in lower-grade meat. Also shows right and wrong methods of preparing road and railway trucks for transport of animals, of treating animals prior to transit and in transit, of loading and unloading animals.

results.title: Do it yourself cartoon kit
results.brief_description: A satire on cartoons, home hobbyists, and box-top specials, in which the viewer is offered an animation kit, complete with noises, cut-out characters and stick-anything adhesive glue, all for fifty guineas and three detergent box tops. Very much in the Monty Python style - made by Keith Learner, Nancy Hanna, Bob Godfrey and Vera Linnecar.

results.title: Do it his way: a case for adapted intelligence tests
results.brief_description: Children with handicaps are often placed at a distinct disadvantage by most intelligence tests. This film advocates adapting tests to fit the needs of a child’s handicap so that true abilities can be measured. Psychologist Zola Anderson modifies psychological testing procedures to fit the abilities of a six-year-old child with cerebral palsy and a four-year-old child with mild mental retardation.

results.title: DNA: molecule of heredity
results.creator_credit: Larry Yust and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology Program. Unit 5. Heredity and Adaptive Change”.
Dr. George Beadle, discoverer of DNA and Nobel prize winner, explains why DNA, a giant molecule of the cell chromosomes, is the basis of growth and reproduction and the mechanism for transporting hereditary specifications from one generation to the next.
